title: Verified Purchase
content: This book drew me in from the first paragraph. The author‚Äôs descriptive writing provides a detailed picture of each scene and each person. Interestingly the author toggles between the far past and the present until a long bout in the past brings the reader up to the present. The characters are all flawed and real. It is as if you‚Äôve stepped into one family‚Äôs life and are learning about everyone who touched it. Be sure to either keep a notebook of all the characters or google for a list.

title: Verified Purchase

title: Book broke apart
content: The Paper Palace will be your next favorite book and deserves a spot on your top ten list. This literary masterpiece is Miranda Heller‚Äôs first novel. One day at their family summer Cape Cod retreat, Elle, mother of three and happily married to Peter, finally has sex with Jonas, her best friend from childhood through her teens whom she probably should have married. Three pages into the novel, Elle thinks, ‚ÄúI love him. I hate myself; I love myself,  I hate him.‚Äù For the rest of the novel, Elle wrestles with whether to leave Peter, whom she also still loves. Elle grew up with parents and grandparents who divorced often. A sad part of the book is Elle‚Äôs protectiveness of her mother. After her mother‚Äôs broken marriages, she finally finds a man who makes her happy. However, to protect her mom and that peaceful happiness, Elle keeps a harmful secret that leads to a tragedy at Cape Cod and connects her emotionally to Jonas forever. This book is beautifully written. Normally I skim over detailed descriptions of nature, but I found myself jotting down some of Heller‚Äôs phrasing about the ocean, campsites, and swimming. Pay attention to what she says about swimming. It‚Äôs a metaphor for the book‚Äôs ending which I am sure you will want to discuss as thousand of readers are debating it on several on-line forums and at book clubs. This deeply emotional book is on several best book lists and Target and Reese‚Äôs Book Clubs. I will read this book again.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2021

title: Verified Purchase
content: I bought this book right after hearing the author interviewed by Mary Louise Kelley on NPR. Together they made it sound like a "must read." Well, I am mostly a non-fiction reader, do not enjoy novels written in first person and find tedious description, that does NOT move the plot, unbearable. So I am amazed that I finished this book as if it were a page turner for me.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Firstly, the Author jumps around continuously through the entire book. Every chapter is a different state, country, era, of someone‚Äôs life- the main character‚Äôs mother, the main character herself, her father, their random spouses. Some of these chapters are completely pointless and irrelevant to the plot or the book itself- which I‚Äôm not sure there truly is a plot, aside from the character screwing a childhood friend?  Is that really an entertaining story? Not so much.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2024

title: Disappointed
content: Story bounced back and forth in time every 2 or 3 pages.  And there was more real ending.  It was a good story line though.  I  Don't recommend it.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: After reading too many "highly rated" poorly written books, this book opened like a breath of fresh air.  The writing was just so good.  As I read on, I couldn't put it down.  Yes, there were things that bothered me that I was able to overlook.  For example, after years of denying their love, Jonas turns Elle around and takes her from behind.  Why?  And, how many perverts does a person encounter in one's life?  What is the author's point creating a character that not only encounters sexual abuse in her childhood home but seems to run into it on the streets wherever she lives?  Why was the additional street violence a necessary element to the story?  Why had Jonas and Elle NEVER considered that Rosemary was a victim as well, and why did this knowledge so easily absolve them of their crime?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2021

title: Desperate to love this book  Spoiler alert
content: Again, all of this I was able to ignore until I got to the ending.  The author has coyly suggested that she never meant for it to be open-ended, that the answer to who Elle chose is in the penultimate paragraph.  Readers have been left feeling confused.  I was left feeling confused until I re-read the end and came to the only logical conclusion.  The ending wasn't cleverly open-ended.  It was, in fact poorly conceived and written.  Once you come to that simple fact, you are free from this book that could have been so much better.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This was just a slow and tortuous chore for me. It was well written, quite lyrical at times, so it wasn't that. I just couldn't relate to, nor did I like, any of the characters. I simply couldn't care what happened to them, whether they found happiness. The most appealing character to me was Elle's mother. At least she had some spunk. Got 1/3 through and then, something I rarely do, just quit.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023

title: Couldn't get through this one
content: It was a good book. Kept me on my toes. I didn‚Äôt love the end. But it‚Äôs possible that I didn‚Äôt fully understand it.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: I gave three stars, and I would have given two and a half. It was very well written, and I thoroughly enjoyed being taken through the vistas of this characters life. I also enjoyed the command of time this author wrote with as she fluidly moved back and forth between memories and present time. That said, while I appreciated the potential each of the character of this story had, I didn‚Äôt at any time, feel like they had any depth. There wasn‚Äôt enough substance to even the main character to feel a connection. When we come into the present time, after most of the middle and very significant years of the characters life being glossed over in a few very short paragraphs I am left with as many questions and potential conclusions as I had throughout the entire story. If this was a book about a frustrated character, then the author succeeded in creating a shared frustration in the reader. If this was a story communicating divorce fragments a child‚Äôs development, then was the author attempting to convey the message through fragmented storytelling? It never completely becomes clear. The main character throughout the story only ever has the weight of the paper dolls she and her sister made as children. A lot of very significant events happen throughout the story and are never fleshed out. No one relationship is ever delved into enough.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2022

title: Good read
content: I purchased this book without reading any reviews, based solely on the jacket synopsis. Now, as I recommend it to friends, I am reading reviews and feel the need to contribute. As a writing instructor with degrees in literary criticism, this book left me speechless in some ways. As others have written, there are scenes of sexual assault that might trigger some readers. And they are sometimes written about with such nonchalance that makes the violence being described feel even worse. However, because those scenes are discussed in first-person, the psychology of the victims cannot be ignored. This novel is brilliantly constructed and themes of family, trauma, love, etc. are woven together masterfully. This is not some easy, light-hearted "summer read." It is literature. The kind of literature that belongs on a University syllabus. It is heartbreaking, funny, infuriating, heartwarming. If you can get through the ugly parts, you will not be able to put it down. Read it carefully and thoughtfully and this is a story that will stay with you for a long, long time. A place that will feel familiar by the end. Characters that you will recognize. I will read everything this author creates, from this point forward. The Paper Palace is something special.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2024

It felt as if the author was in love with him, willing to overlook his flaws. From the moment when he stays Elle‚Äôs hand on the boat to the last moment in the book, he is singularly focused on what he wants. It is Elle, not Jonas, who pays the price.

title: Intense storyline‚Ä¶interesting read
content: I‚Äôm sorry I spent a few valuable hours of my precious lifetime on Earth reading the first half of this book before I deleted it from my kindle. I‚Äôm sorrier I didn‚Äôt read the reviews earlier, which might have tipped me off to go and do something else. I decided to read it while visiting the area of the Cape where the book is set. There‚Äôd been some buzz about it. I‚Äôd heard the author interviewed, and she seemed like a character. If only her fictional characters were as intriguing. The descriptions of the outer Cape landscape are good, hence, the one well-deserved star. The characters ... I couldn‚Äôt find a single one to care about, except maybe the giant snapping turtle whose indignant rage I found relatable. Lots of trite, predictable descriptions heavily peppered with sexual assault and abuse to, I don‚Äôt know, be provocative and ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù? {sigh} If you empty a bottle of hot sauce onto your SpaghettiOs, they‚Äôre still SpaghettiOs, only now they make your eyes water‚Äîwhich in the case of this book may be a blessing because tears are cleansing. Anyway, for sure there are books about despicable characters who commit horrendous deeds that are good books‚Äîthe characters are still somehow sympathetic, and their actions serve the greater purpose of the narrative and art. You think to yourself, ‚ÄúWow, that book made me think of something I haven‚Äôt thought of before! It didn‚Äôt make me feel bored or icky at all! I sure am glad I read that book!‚Äù This is not one of those books.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: However, lots of people seem to like this book. You might be one of those people. Read the other reviews. If they resonate, don‚Äôt mind me. But if you‚Äôre a cranky, picky reader too exhausted to read yet another book ponderously chronicling the sticky dregs of human nature to no meaningful end, stop right there, turn off your phone, and go pet a puppy or smile at a baby or something. You‚Äôll be glad that you did.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2022

title: Was okay.
content: The writing was beautiful, the metaphors lovely, the story pulled me in immediately, and I couldn't put it down, but every one of Elle's decisions made me cringe. From cheating on her husband, a man she admired and loved, to constantly breaking her lover's heart, to letting her step-brother molester her every night for the most absurd reason, I kept hoping I'd find some redeeming qualities, but no, I felt only disgust. I know it's a popular story line now to feature flawed heroes, but when your own life is not a train wreck, it's hard to be really fulfilled by a book that makes you feel sorry for all the people in Elle's life. Thus I'm conflicted.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Some books are so overhyped and I grow weary even to finish them because the hype was basically ALL . BUT #thepaperpalace is a different story. It came up on an Instagram feed I follow (NOT a famous person‚Äôs) and I ordered it based on what she said - which was very little- other than WOW. This novel ~ wow ~ (the word applies!!) I kept rereading as I went because I didn‚Äôt want to miss a thing‚Ä¶I also didn‚Äôt want it to end. The structure fascinated me - the present point of view is ONE DAY but the past goes way back and is omnipresent throughout the narrative of the one day (it‚Äôs just that way in real life too) We see Elle‚Äôs life as she ponders, reflects, and wonders what comes next‚Ä¶ There are three generations meeting on #capecod and they will permeate your head and heart as that day unfolds. You won‚Äôt see what happens from sunrise to sunrise coming, but you will turn those pages! #againandagain
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2021

title: Mesmerizing in structure and style!
content: The characters were severely underdeveloped in my opinion and i did not feel any connection to them/ care what happened to them whatsoever. To me, the sequence in which the book was written was very confusing and just seemed like a string of random, unfortunate events that didn‚Äôt have anything to do with the present. It was way too confusing to have so much back story about mothers and grandmothers that also had little impact on the actual story. I kept waiting to feel more attachment to the characters, and was just disappointed. It seems like there was just tragedy after tragedy thrown together in attempt to make an interesting story and to make readers feel bad for the main character. I just found it to be demoralizing at times and not easy to follow. Each traumatic event was just blatantly stated without a story developing from it. The story felt very scattered and disconnected with none of the tragedies connecting and too many irrelevant characters being convinced. I found myself being confused and struggling to remember who was who every time I picked up the book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2023

title: Verified Purchase

I'm treading lightly here so as not to spoil anything. Those who have read the book will know what I'm talking about.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I thought the book's ending was a bit ambiguous, then I read the acknowledgements and knew the ending. Initially, the going into the past and back to the present was confusing, until going back to the past dealt with what was the former present. Overall, it was a book that I read faster than most; I didn't want it to end.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2022

title: Beautifully written!
content: It's hard to know what to say about this book. It's so deep and tangled. The unwavering love and connection she has with Jonas is familiar and it was easy to get lost in as I was reading. The tragedy in each person's life is sometimes hard to read through. Watching these imperfect people stumble through life, products of those before them, is so real and palpable. Some people had a hard time with the ending because it appeared to be abrupt but in reality, it's not. Here you are in present day, after reading about the preceding decades and she has a decision to make and that's pretty much it. Otherwise she would have been telling the same story over and over. The amount of healing Elle goes through was beautifully crafted by the author. I'm excited to read more from her.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2021

title: Verified Purchase
content: I usually don‚Äôt write negative book reviews because I understand how much of one‚Äôs heart and soul goes into the writing process.  This is going to be the exception.  The reason for the negative review is the nonchalant depictions of incest, rape, and childhood sexual abuse.  If you are going to use these themes, you better make sure it leaves a powerful impact on the destruction and damage it physically, emotionally and psychologically causes the abused. It this book, it was just a casual theme thrown in the mix almost normalizing it as acceptable.  We have enough of this in society and in Hollywood, we don‚Äôt need more.  This book is also boring.  Really boring.  I kept waiting for it to go somewhere but it never did.  I kept waiting for a plot twist, never happened.

title: Ehhhh
content: This was novel was at times difficult to read. The sexual encounters are a little graphic but it is the brutal sexual assaults on women that make it a tough read. I did not read this novel for a long time because I have always found adultery distasteful. I was afraid that I would dislike the main character, Eleanor, so why bother. The backstory, is what is so amazing, as to why Eleanor betrays her husband. There are so many flawed characters in this novel. The women are judged so harshly. This novel makes it seem that women have no control over their libido and that as a consequence their children will suffer. There a very few nice characters in this novel and they are both men.

title: a stunningly gorgeous book
content: The author takes us through several long term family and other relationships of a very fortunate but very conflicted woman.  She is beautiful, wealthy, loved, and gifted but nevertheless lacking in self assurance in critical circumstances.  We go back and forth between periods in her life when she makes major choices that often satisfy but also haunt her.  We see how her family members help shape her, but don't ultimately determine what she decides.  The Cape Cod setting reminds me of New England summer vacations I've experienced, with a certain specialness of place and friendship that seeped into my bones and shaped my outlook.  The descriptions of the family place are vivid and so are the characters.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: Such an amazing story and so well crafted and beautifully written. I will not forget this book and the memories it brought back to me of the lessons I've learned through the course of my life and the questions brought to me over time.
